column2: The regular meeting of the Citizens' Reform Committee was held last evening, at No. 185 Montague-street. That section of the proposed charter relating to the Board of Education which provides that after the year 1872 the Board shall be reduced to one member from each district, to be appointed by the Mayor was tabled for the present.

The Committee appointed by the Citizens' mass-meeting held last Friday evening, to confer with Commodore VANDERBILT upon the sinking of the Fourth-avenue track, held their first meeting last evening at East-side Association Hall, WHEELER H. PECKHAM presiding. Judge W.B. BEEBER stated that several members of the Committee had called upon Com modore VANDERBILT in relation to the matter, and had found him inclined to consider the sub- ject in the most liberal manner.

Seven members of the Reform Board of Aldermen are in favor of appointing JOSEPH SHANNON Clerk of the Board. Here is a lump of Tammany leaven with a vengeance. WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. The ridiculous stories in circulation to the effect that the Spanish Minister has demanded his passports, and that the President has made a vigorous demand on Spain in the case of the Florida, have not a particle of foundation.
President GRANT returned to Washington yesterday.

It was of course, superbly interpreted. Mr. THOMAS musicians have performed side by side...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. Congress reassembled today with a large list of absentees, and without much spirit manifest in either branch. In the House a great avalanche of bills was introduced, few of them being of any special importance. Nearly the whole day was spent in fruitless attempts to get the rules suspended...

In view of the probability that all the available naval force at the various Yards may soon be called into action, it will be interesting to the public to know the exact condition of the ships now lying at the Brooklyn Navy-Yard. There is at present a force of about 1,200 men on the pay-roll, which can be increased in case of emergency to more than four times that number.

The call of States for bills being concluded, Mr. LYNCH, of Maine, offered a resolution requesting the president to take steps to ascertain the views of European Governments in reference to international co-operation in the construction of a ship-canal between the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans. Referred, on motion of Mr. BANKS, of Massachusetts, to the Committee on Foreign Affairs.

Early last evening a reporter rang the door-bell of the brown-stone mansion, No. 359 West Twenty-third-street, occupied by Mrs. HELEN JOSEPHINE MANSFIELD, and waited for admittance. The heavy outside door was locked, the hall was dark, and the windows of the first floor omitted but a very faint light. In a few seconds a woman came to the door and opened it sufficiently wide to allow her to look through.
The Sabbath-school of the Graham-avenue Methodist Church repeat their anniversary exercises this evening.

The Board of Aldermen for 1872 organized, yesterday afternoon, by the election of the officers named in the TIMES of yesterday. JACOB I. BERGEN, Esq., presided. After the organization the Mayor's Message was received, of which the following is the substance:

The jury in the case of the late JAMES FISK, Jr., were called together by Coroner YOUNG, yesterday morning, and met at the Erie Railroad office, where they were sworn by him. The late residence of the deceased, No. 313 Weat Twenty third-street was next visited, where the body of the murdered man was viewed by the jury.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 8. The trial of Mrs. WHARTON was resumed at 10 A.M., and the examination of Dr. HARVEY L. BYRD was continued. He reiterated his statement that Gen. KETCHUM did not die from poison by tartar emetic, as the symptoms and characteristic lesions were wanting; he died from natural cause, probably from cerebro-spinal miningitis...

It should be understood by members of the Legislature that if that portion at least of Senator BENEDICT'S bill, authorizing the immediate issue of some six millions of bonds, be not pressed, the City, will be bankrupt in open market, and an immense injury will be done to the public credit.

The Board of Aldermen effected a permanent organization yesterday afternoon. It met at two o'clock, but long before that hour a crowd had assembled outside the Aldermanic Chamber, and impatiently awaited the opening of the doors.

The funeral ceremonies over the body of the late JAMES FISK., Jr., yesterday, attracted one of the largest crowds ever assembled together in this City. The extraordinary circumstances surrounding the tragedy, coupled with the notoriety of the principals, gave to yesterday's events an interest which otherwise would not attach itself to the obsequies of a man like the deceased.

The case of MURRAY against COULTER, involving the right to the Police Justiceship of the Yorkville Police Court, was continued on trial before Judge BRADY and a jury in Part II, of the Supreme Court, yesterday. The testimony, with few exceptions, was merely confirmatory of what has been already published.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 9. In the trial of Mrs. WHARTON the direct examination of Dr. McCLURG was continued, and in his cross-examination he adhered to his opinion given yesterday, that Gen. KETCHUM died from cerebrospinal meningitis, in a semi-fulminant form.

The Board of Assistant Aldermen succeeded in electing a President yesterday, thereby effecting a permanent organization. It met at 4 o'clock with Alderman SCHWARTZ in the chair. The lobbies were thronged with spectators, by whom much interest in the proceedings was manifested.

BRATTLEBORO. Vt., Jan. 9. The body of Col. JAMES Fisk, Jr., arrived here about 11 o'clock last evening on the express train bound for Montreal. A large concourse of people were in waiting at the depot, and escorted the funeral cortege to the Revere House, where ample accommodations had been provided for the mourners and friends accompanying the remains of the deceased.

The People ex rel. Christian Schwarts vs. A. Oakey Hall; peremptory writ granted.
The New-York mail from San Francisco arrived last evening at about 10 o'clock.
In the Senate this evening, the Lieutenant- Governor presented a communication declining to appoint the balance of the Committees left vacant by Senator WOODIN.

ALBANY, Jan 9.?The Legislature reassembled this evening with more than a quorum in both Houses. The session was brief, and the interest mainly confined to the Assembly, where, in accordance with general expectation, the standing committees were announced by Speaker SMITH. The Speaker had been unusually successful...
The inquiry into the manner of the death of JAMES FISK, Jr., was resumed yesterday afternoon, at 3 o'clock, by Coroner YOUNG, in the Court of Special Sessions.

The old maxim which tells us to speak nothing but good of the dead was not uttered in vain. Its author is unknown; for it is one of many sayings that have come to us out of the darkness of the past, and which are venerated quite as much for the antiquity and the uncertainty of their origin as for the wisdom they embody.

UTICA, N. Y., Jan. 9.?The seventh annual Convention of the American Dairymen's Association was commenced today in this city. The meeting was called to order, at 10 o'clock A.M., by Hon. HORATIO SEYMOUR, when Mr. M.S. HAWLEY moved the appointment of the Standing Committees, and the motion was carried. The Chair accordingly made the following nominations:
Gen. HALLECK died at his residence, in Louisville, at 8:25 o'clock last evening, of congestion of the brain, superinduced by disease of the liver, with which he had been afflicted for some time.

For "at least a week" New-York is to have a new Mayor, or, rather, an acting Mayor. The flat has gone forth. Mayor HALL has issued the proclamation, and for a week to come his chair at the City Hall is to be occupied by the new President of the Board of Aldermen.

None of the friends of Mr. CONNOLLY about the City Hall yesterday attempted to deny that he was out of the City. It was hinted, moreover, that though within a few hours' ride of the City, and ready to come back when deemed necessary, he was at the same time ready for flight when warned. There is certainly a mysterious silence about his whereabouts.
Both Houses of the Legislature organized at 3 o'clock this afternoon by electing Republican officers. In the Senate there was no opposition to the re-election of the old officers.

The bill providing for the payment of bonds of New-York City falling due this month was passed.

On Monday night Mr. JAMES STEELE MACKAYE opened the little St. James Theatre for a dramatic season of which he is to be the chief feature. The house was well filled and the audience was favorably disposed.

The amount of railroad business which is already before the Legislature, as shown by the petitions in the Secretary's office, plainly shows the nature of the work to which the coming session will be devoted.
WM. M. TWEED was visited by a TIMES reporter yesterday, at his office, No. 25 Duanesteet.
McFARLAND'S distillery, at Sagetown, Ill., was burned Monday, Loss, $20,000. DAVID LEAVITT, attached to the Boston Journal, died of apoplexy yesterday.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 10. The injunction suit before Judge DIBBLE, which was to have come off this morning, referred to in my last dispatch, has been adjourned until Saturday next. Outside the Warmoth politicians, the opinion prevails that this proceeding before the Eighth District Court is a farce, and that before Saturday, it will be dismissed.

The reputation of the much-laughed at WAGNER grows space and, from the latest signs, the music of the future bids fair to become the music of the present. It is a singular and interesting fact that Italy, which has hitherto treated the pretensions of the German composer with utter contempt, is at this moment going wild over "Lohengrin." Early in November the opera was broughtout with many misgivings at Bologna.
The Vice-President appointed the following special committee to investigate the charges against Senator CLAYTON: Messrs. WRIGHT, of Iowa; MORRILL, of Maine, and NORWOOD, of Georgia.

A correspondent was given an opportunity a few days ago to express in our columns his disappointment at not getting from a prom- inent life insurance company so large a dividend as usual. Two or three communications have since been received by us, by way of explanation. Without discussing the question with reference to any par ticular company, we may properly say a few words about life insurance and its present position in public estimation.

A case concerning a picture has lately been tried in London which assumed a more than mere local interest, by reason of the remarkable link which the chattel in dispute had with a variety of notable charac- ters and incidents.

The rumors that CESPEDES had fled from Cuba have been denied both by his wife and the Vice-President of the Cuban Republic, who are now in this City. Col. UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 10.?After sending the dispatch of yesterday a meeting was held at 7 P.M. at the Court-house, where a paper was read by H. COOLEY GREEN. Esq., on the manufacture of butter in creameries. Mr. GREEN illustrated his plan with a mop churner on a large scale, and used many arguments to prove that the co-operative system was the correct one.

BERLIN, Jan. 10. The Provincial Correspondenz, in its issue today says the re-establishment of diplomatic relations with France proves that, the German Government wishes to restore the former friendly relations between the two nations.

The session of the Legislature today was brief and devoid of interest. The bill for the financial relief of New-York City passed both Houses without opposition, after having been amended as indicated in last night's dispatch.

Acting Mayor COCHRANE, who, in accordance with the proclamation of the temporarily retired Mayor, is to act in such capacity for" at least a week," arrived at the Mayor's office be- fore noon of yesterday, and assumed the new duties which have been imposed upon him. He remained there until 4 o'clock and was waited upon by a large number of his personal friends and City officials.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. Mr. CONKLING'S speech today, of which announcement has been made, was one of the ablest of the many masterly orations made by him in the Senate. It was listened to with marked attention by a full Senate Chamber and well-filled galleries. The choice of the place for the Convention was made after a full presentation of the claims of Cincinnati, the only other city whose citizens made any...

It is questionable whether Senator SUMNER'S proposition for a "one-term amendment" to the Constitution requires very serious discussion. The circumstances under which the proposition is brought forward, the form which is given it, the time chosen to offer it, force the conclusion that it is really little better than frivolous. Senator CONKLING thoroughly exhausts the whole question in an able speech which we reprint this morning in full.

The Board of Aldermen met yesterday afternoon. Every member was in his seat, and the concourse of spectators present was sufficient to fill every foot of space allotted to the public. Acting Mayor COCHRANE presided.
Messrs, AMES, ALLEN, and LORD were appointed a committee to investigate the charges in the New-York Tribune against Senator JAMES WOOD, with power to send for persons and papers.

Mr. TRUMBULL, of Illinois, presented a large number of petitions from several of the States, for the reduction of the tariff to a strictly revenue basis, and especially for the repeal of the protective duties on iron, coal and salt. The petitions, he said, were signed by about 7,000 of the leading men of the State from which they came. Referred to the Committee on Finance.

The Senate managed to get through all the business before them in an hour's session this morning. Several bills were introduced, among which was one for an underground railroad in New-York, commonly known as the Vandenbergh scheme, being a tunnel road under Broadway, with a capital of $10,000,000. The same bill has been before the Legislature in past years.

The House Committee on Foreign Affairs this morning considered the question of fixing a day for discussion of Cuban affairs, but failed to come to any agreement. They also considered the Alta Vela bill, which was subsequently reported to the House.

NEW?ORLEANS, Jan. 11.?There is comparative quiet today. After the Carterites fled to the Custom-house, the Warmoth Police, as did also their commander, performed the same feat as was performed by a certain French King?marched up the hill and then marched down again. The Warmoth Legislature has been reinforced by the attendance of some of the Carter absentees today in the House of Representatives, but no proceedings of especial importance took place.

Savings banks and banks of deposit and discount being established and maintained for entirely different purposes, there should naturally be a great difference in their methods of conducting business. Banks of deposit and discount are intended to facilitate the financial operations of merchants and traders generally, and it was in furtherance of this design that the present system of checks was adopted.

The Grand Jury entered the Court of General Sessions yesterday, at noon. The foreman, LUCIUS S. COMSTOCK, addressing the Court, said: We have no indictments to present to your Honor this morning, but we have a subject under consideration in the Grand Jury room that we consider important, which we propose to present to the Court, and through the Court to the public Press. BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 25. The severest snow-storm that has occurred here for several years past prevailed all day. The ferry-boat plying between Fort Erie and Black Rock during the blinding snow-storm ran aground, and remains there.

The dangers of the Navy-yard district in Brooklyn have again been vividly illustrated by the shocking murder of the musicteacher, Mr. PANORMO, on Tuesday evening. The unhappy gentleman left his boardinghouse at 8 o'clock to keep a professional engagement at No. 41 Cumberland-street, between Park and Flushing avenues.

We gave a day or two since a full and fair statement of the facts of the General Order business, as they appear before the Committee of the Senate. It will be for that Committee to consider whether the system should continue as at present, and if not what change should be made. We, however, express our own decided opinion that the present system should be abolished.

In accordance with an order issued by the Controller of the Currency, the Ocean Bank, yesterday morning, began to pay its depositors thirty per cent of its deposits. A sad domestic tragedy, having its origin in dissipation, and passing through the usual phases of domestic unhappiness, culminated yesterday afternoon in the death of a youth, an only son at the hands of his crazed father, and in the serious wounding of the murderer in endeavoring to terminate his own existence. The principal actor in this terrible tragedy in real life is HENRY HEPNER, a native of Germany.

MARSCHNER'S opera of "The Templar and the Jewess," which has been familiar to German audiences for many years, but which, until yesterday, was unknown in the United States, was sung last evening at the Stadt Theatre. It is a thoroughly interesting work, and bears no more apparent traces of age than "Der Freyschuetz," which preceded it by a brief space of time only.

In the Common Council, yesterday Alderman ROPES offered a resolution directing the Law Committee to report whether it is expedient to increase the Police force, in view of the lawlessness which prevails at present, and if so to make the necessary application to the Legislature. Alderman BERGEN stated that there was no necessity of applying to the Legislature, as the Board has already the power to increase the force. On motion the resolution was tabled.

A young minister said by some journals to be of the Baptist persuasion, but whose regular connection with the sect is denied by others has been committed to jail in Cincinnati for robbery. His name is STEPHEN MORGAN, his birthplace Wales, and he has been in this country two years.

He complained of the omission because it renderedd his own succeeding remark unintelligible. A vigorous attempt is being made to exaggerate the significance of the bolting scheme in Missouri, which has usurped the name of "Liberal Republican." We do not understand that the Committee of Seventy claim, by any means, that their proposed form of charter may not be amend- ed to advantage in the Legislature. They submit it simply as embodying the general idea of the Committee, and as having the advantage of having been carefully matured in all its parts, and of having had the parts well considered with reference to the whole.

One thing should be clearly understood by our citizens and legislators, and that is, that if certain public abuses connected with New-York as a port of entry be not corrected, the commerce of this City will be seriously injured. The commanding posi- tion of New-York, at the mouth of a great river and at the terminus of so many railways, can never be entirely undermined.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 30. An Erie mail train bound East at 11 o'clock last night was thrown from the track two miles this side of Lock Haven. One baggage-car, two coaches and one sleeping-car were burned. The express car was saved-by the contents of the stove being thrown into the safe. A large amount of money was burned. Several persons were injured, and one whose name is unknown, cannot survive.

Every one of ordinary intelligence is aware that illuminating gas is obtained by the distillation of coal. The process is extremely simple. The coal is placed in a closely-stopped iron oven, a furnace below is ignited, and as the coal is wasted the fumes and vapors pass through pipes, and, after undergoing more or less of purification, the gas is collected in a gasholder, and thence served out to the public.

This is a rule without an exception, and its application has been long conceded by every party to its opponents. WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. The French arms debate is substantially ended, though another field day of talk is probable on Friday, to which day the Senate adjourned over WASHINGTON'S birthday, to-morrow.

The recent excitement occasioned by the gas question has given rise to much investigation on this vexed subject. It must not be supposed that the Austrian dominions are no longer the scene of chronic grumbling. If the wails of Bohemia have lately seemed faint, it is only because she received so severe a snub in the downfall of her ally, Count HOHENWART, from the Ministry a few months ago, that she is, for a time, giving vent only to suppressed sobs. Whereupon Galicia promptly takes the opportunity to make her cry heard.

The Committee are pushing matters with the utmost expedition.

LEWIS, of the late firm of LEWIS GOODWIN, testified that in 1868 he put in a bid to furnish diagrams at ten cents each; GOODWIN received thirty cents each that year; I think it was addressed in proper form to C.W. ARMSTRONG, who was then Clerk; did not bid for Senate diagrams.

The Pere GRATRY was buried today in the Cemetery of Mont Parnasse. The funeral service took place in the small church of the Mission-Etrangeres. When I went to the church, half an hour before the appointed time, I found it already almost filled.

Senator SCHURZ'S friends are showing evident symptoms of distress. ELIZA WILKINSON, aged twenty-four, was found early, yesterday, in Hester-street, near the Bowery, disabled and suffering from abuse at the hands of two men, as she alleged. She was taken to Bellevue Hospital.
The Catholic societies of Newark are making arrangements for a parade on St. Patrick's Day. They will be joined by a number of societies from New-Brunswick, Trenton and Jersey City.

Mr. BELMONT has sold the imported chestnut colt By the Sea, four years old, by Thornamby, out of Bernice by Stockwell. The purchaser was a Mr. PHELPS, who will shortly ship the horse to South America. The price paid was $1,500.

STOKES, convicted of having received money for prosecuting claims against the Government while he was a Representative in Congress, appeared on the opening of the Court with his counsel, who stated that Gen. The Vice-President, near the close of the debate last night, declined, as he had the right to do under the rules, to appoint the Committee to make the investigation into the sales of arms during 1870. Thus the responsibility was left with the Senate itself as to how the Committee should be composed. Mr. SUMNER declined in advance to serve.
LONDON, March 1 Evening. The assailant of the Queen was brought before the Police Magistrates at Bow-street, at noon today, for examination.

Mr. GREELEY justifies his opposition to Gen. GRANT'S renomination on the ground that he has always been adverse to the reelection of an incumbent. If this was his sole or strongest reason, there could be no objection to his arguing the question within the Republican organization, in a spirit of candor and friendship, as a point entitled to the consideration of his friends.

PORTLAND, Me., March 4. At the charter election today, BENJAMIN KINGSBURY, Jr., was re-elected Mayor, the Vote standing KINGSBURY, (Rep.,) 2,032; CLEAVES, (Dem.,) 1,648; MORGAN, (Citizen ticket,) 313; scattering, 12; against, last year. Republican, 2,317; Democrat, 1,932; scattering, 48. At Saco, EDWARD P. BARKLOW, (Rep.,) was elected Mayor by 383 majority. At Bath, JAMES D. ROBINSON, (Rep.,) was re-elected by 57 majority.

A deficiency of nearly $100,000 has been discovered in the accounts of Ex-Controller EVAN M. JOHNSON, of Brooklyn. It first received publicity yesterday afternoon, when, at the meeting of the Board of Aldermen, the following communication from Controller SHROEDER was read, causing much astonishment among the members of that body:
An indignation meeting was held at Hempstead, yesterday, to protest against the location of the Court-house at Mineola.
The town election for Trustees and Treasurer of Yonkers takes place today.

A store has recently been opened on Broadway, which startles the public by the announcement that the Great Geneva Watch Company, after thirty years' business existence, has suddenly collapsed, and that their bankrupt stock is to be had at ridiculously low prices. Upon a visit to the store, watches of all kinds, silver and gold, may be found at prices ranging from $6 to $45.

M. CATACAZY is well known here as a man of a certain ability, but with principles of a very doubtful character. It must be said, to the honor of the Czar, that he put forward serious objections against CATACAZY'S appointment to Washington when it took place. Prince GORTSCHAKOFF, however, was not actuated by such delicate feelings, but pushed his favorite forward at all hazards.
There are now 528 prisoners in the Trenton State Prison. A new lodge of Good Templars is about to be organized in Jersey City.
The produce merchants intend erecting a new editice as an exchange, and advertise for a site.

When the Grand Jury found their indictments against HALL, he loudly and ostentatiously professed his extreme anxiety to have a speedy trial. His burning impatience even outran the preparations of the public prosecutor, and the convenience of the Judge who had been selected to try the case. This greatly maligned official was so conscious of his own rectitude, that to rest for another week under an untried indictment seemed to be perfectly intolerable.

The examination in the conduct of GEORGE W. MILLER as Superintendent of the Insurance Department was renewed yesterday before the Legislative Committee. Mr. LIPPITT occupied the chair and Messrs. BABCOCK, ENOS and ATRISS were present at the opening of the proceedings Mr. POBEY also joined the Committee for a short time during the morning session.
A large cotton-mill is to be speedily erected in Richmond, Va. The Boston Globe, a new daily paper, appeared yesterday.
Yesterday permanent water loan bonds to the amount of $25,000 were issued by the Controller.

The Board of Aldermen met at 3 o'clock P.M. yesterday, President COCHRANE in the chair. A petition was presented by Alderman MEHRBACH from a large number of citizens for relief against the present gas monopoly, which was referred to the Committee on Repairs and Supplies.

WASHINGTON, March 4. The Custom-house investigation was resumed this morning by the Committee, who met for that purpose in the room of the Senate Committee on Pacific Railroads. The session lasted nearly six hours, and the whole time was occupied in the examination of GOD. HORACE PORTER, Acting Secretary to the President.

Mrs. JOHN WOOD, fresh from her newest London triumphs, and from the "indorsement" of that Macaenas of letters and of art, Mr. CHARLES READE, appeared last night at Niblo's Garden. The lady has not acted here before in three years. Her audience, despite the bad weather, was numerous, and her greeting was cordial.

PHILADELPHIA, March 4. The Centennial Commissioners assembled this morning at the Continental, and at noon were escorted to Independence Hall by Committees of the Councils and representatives of the Commercial Exchange, the Franklin Institute, the Board of Trade and the Horticultural society, Mayor STOKLEY was introduced to the Commissioners by JOHN L. SHOEMAKER, and made an address of welcome, which was responded to by ex-Gov. JOSEPH F. HAWLEY, of Connecticut. In concluding he said:

The recent annual report of the Pennsylvania Railroad contains many points of interest, not only to the stockholders, but to the community in general. As the eastern terminus of the road, since the lease of the New-Jersey lines, is practically Jersey City, the people of New-York have a very direct concern in some of these points.

BOSTON, March 5. The thermometer this morning indicated from 2 to 6 below zero, and at noon stood at zero. A strong north-west gale prevailed. Reports from Maine and NewHampshire show a still lower range of thermometer.

CONCORD, N.H., March 5. New-Hampshire is frozen up, politics and all, today. From 6 o'clock last night to 5 his morning there was a change of 58 in temperature, the thermometer changing from 38 above to 20 below. In consequence of this intense cold, the day has been one of enforced quiet, and meetings of both parties to-night, in every part of the State, are poorly attended.
During February 100 cases of small-pox were reported to the Newark health authorities. A fire occurred in the shoe-store of JOHN ENGLEHARDT, in Hoboken, yesterday. Damage, $800.

The town meetings held today in various parts of the State have detained so many members at home that there was barely a quorum present at the opening of the Assembly this morning. This being General Order day, however, their absence did no harm, as experience has shown that the fewer members there are present, the better it is for the dispatch of business in Committee of the Whole.

Jack Frost, it appears, has not left the country. Everybody was feeling happy over the prospect of bright sunny days and pleasant walks, when Jack came back like an infuriated tyrant with a bitter, brutal north-west wind harnessed to his chariot, nor could the beams of a kindly sun dissipate his power. The sprinkling of snow that swept the streets on Monday evening was but an indication of what was coming throughout the night.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5. The fire is still smouldering on the eighth story of the Chestnut-street front of Jaynes' Building, but is under the control of the firemen, and the lower floors are so drenched with water and sheeted with ice that further damage is improbable. The granite front on Chestnut-street is not wholly damaged.

The Tichborne case is ended. The Lenten season usually causes a palpable diminution of audiences at the theatres, but, except at the houses where the current performance consists of pieces that have already had long and prosperous runs, there is, this year, little sign of such falling off. Indeed, the opera, which commonly suffers most from this cause, has been so numerously attended as to make the opening of the Spring season quite a triumph.
There is very little more to be said of a canvass of which but three days now remains, and which has been one of the most thorough and exciting which the Granite State has ever had.

It is an open question still whether woman is to have the ballot and to vote and be voted for in the new times coming, but there can be no question that she is telling as never before in modern society, and that better days for her influence are in store. She is already a great power in literature, and in the number of publications from her pen.

From the standpoint of the picturesque, it seems almost a pity that the fine old science of astrology is so fast falling into disrepute and neglect. Time was when kings and queens were counted among its patrons, and the great ones of the earth sought its aid to circumvent their enemies, or propitiate the more inexorable fates. Even in its delusions there was often something akin to grandeur.

The abatement in the severity of the weather yesterday foreshadows the approach of Spring, though we may yet experience a few cold days before the end of March. the rain did a little toward cleaning our neglected streets, though the lower portions of the City were never in a more wretched condition than now, owing to the masses of ice and flith with which they are choked.

The last working night but one of the canvass in New-Hampshire has been fully improved by the Republicaus, large meetings having been held at all the important points, and there was an increased enthusiasm and confidence manifested everywhere, so far as reports have been received by the State Committees. At Portsmouth the meeting was addressed by Gen. WALTER HARRIMAN with his accustomed ability.

There is a class of enterprising women who have discovered that an easy and comfortable livelihood can be made by practicing upon the fears of the timid traveler.

Rev. WM. M. TAYLOR, of Liverpool, recently elected minister of the Broadway Tabernacle Church, preached his first sermon there yesterday morning. The church was densely crowded. There is, we all know, no accounting for tastes. Perhaps of all tastes, one which those who do not share it find the greatest difficulty in understanding, is that for funerals.

WASHINGTON, March 10. The Civil Service Advisory Board, which has continued its labors through good report and evil report, is now about ready to present a supplemental report to the President. The regulations for carrying into effect the principles laid down in the general rules adopted the 1st of January have all been decided upon and are embodied in the report about to be made.

It has been known for sometime past that the Banking and Currency Committee of the House of Representatives was prosecuting an inquiry into certain official acts of the Controller of the Currency. So long as the facts elicited were kept by the Committee in strict confidence, there could be no propriety in alluding to so grave a subject as that involving the personal and official character of a prominent public officer.

JOHN was arrested and locked up in the Church-street Police Station.

Home affairs of every kind have been forgotten during the past week by the excitement-loving Havanese, the presence of the Grand Duke ALEXIS having for the time absorbed all other matters. One of the most interesting of antiquarian studies is that which relates to the origin and purpose of the many ancient mounds and monuments found in almost every country. There is in the mystery that attaches itself, to our own "grave mounds" at the West, as well as to the huge stone monuments at Stonehenge, in England, something exceedingly attractive to the modern mind.

BUFFALO, March 12.--Rail SHIPMENTS--1,400 bushels Wheat. FLOUR quiet; sales, 250 bbls, to city dealers. WHEAT dull; sales, 450 bushels White Mich igan at $1.75, CORN dull; sales, 2 cars Western at 58c.; 2 cars Western at 57c., on the track. WASHINGTON, March 12.--Of the $140,000,000 of five-twenty bonds called in for redemption by the Treasury Department, $23,000,000 now bear no interest. Of the $100,000,000 called in Dec. 1, 1871, $91,005,900 have been redeemed. Of the $20,000,000 called for March 7 only $8,125,950 have been redeemed, and of the $20,000,000 called for March 20 only $5,149,950 have yet been redeemed. The bonds come in very slowly.

CINCINNATI, March 18. The boiler of Messrs. JONES CORNAHAUS' soap and candle factory, on Central-avenue, exploded at 2 o'clock today, killing two men JACOB ASTHREF and GEORGE HERLINGER. A piece of the boiler, sixteen feet long, and weighing 3,000 pounds, was blown a distance of nearly hair a mile, and killed three children, named CORA COLE. ALICE THORNTON and ELLA FORBES. The cause of the explosion is unknown.

In the "Presidential" year the March election in New-Hampshire usually prefigures that of November in the whole country. And this is not a mere coincidence. In a closely balanced State the condition of political feeling in the Spring is not likely to change before the Autumn, except for very serious reasons, and it may be expected that the majority in March will be proportionately greater in November.

The final performances of the present version of "Humpty Dumpty" are now occurring at the Olympic Theatre. As the figures stand, Gov. JEWELL is fairly ahead of the field, and he will secure a re-election on a popular vote.

RONDOUT, April 7. The crossing of the first train over the Walkill Valley Railway Bridge was celebrated at Rosedale yesterday. About 5,000 people were present, including many prominent men from various points in the vicinity. The first train over consisted of an engine, tender and seven cars. The test was completely satisfactory, the bridge showing no signs of weakness.

GOODMAN'S STATION, Fla., April 8. GOV. REED has issued a proclamation declaring his intention of retaining possession of the Gubernatorial office. It is the opinion of the best lawyers of the State that the decision will be in GOV. REED'S favor.

Hon. ERASTUS CORNING died on Monday evening at Albany, after a long and severe illness, at the age of seventy-eight years. He was born at Norwich, Conn., in December, 1794, receiving comparatively few educational advantages.

While it is true that there is a world-wide value for diamonds in general, there is now more than ever before a critical taste for gems. There is as much difference between diamonds as there is between the brilliance of an hydro-oxygen jet and the sparkle of an ordinary flame.

Arrivals from Camargo, with dates to the 17th inst., report that the revolutionists fined the firm of BUCK, SCHONFIELDT Co., of Monterey, $35,000 for some irregularity in passing money out of the country. The Allgemeine Saengerbund and its sing ing-school gave the last vocal and musical entertainment of the season at the Germania Assembly Rooms last evening. The Colonia Vocal Society gave a successful entertainment at its club-rooms, in the Bowery, last evening.

The Annual Conference of the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church was held in this City last week. This Church is an organization composed exclusively of colored people, and inasmuch as the Methodist Episcopal Church is entirely willing to receive colored converts on terms of exact equality with white brethren, there does not seem to be any necessity for the separate existence of a colored Methodist society.

The Republican State Convention elected six delegates for the State at large to the Philadelphia Convention. Of these, CHARLES J. He is well educated, well, bred, very intelligent and a good speaker.

A jury more interesting to the student of morbid psychology, than the jury which assisted at the trial of Mrs. FANNY HYDE has, perhaps, never been assembled. The stupid juryman, who can never fully comprehend who the defendant is, and who has a conviction that the District-Attorney is really the criminal on trial; the obstinate juryman, who declines to be influenced by the plainest evidence; the juryman of obtrusive silliness.

The title of the case is The National Exchange Bank of Milwaukee vs. David Dows et al., and its conclusions will come like a legal revelation to people who are accustomed to believe that a bill of lading will hold property against the claim of the true owner.

WASHINGTON, April, 23. Mr. WHEELER, Chairman of the House Pacific Railroad Committee, called up today the motion to reconsider the vote whereby the Yerba Buena Island bill was recommitted to the Committee with instructions, some time since, to amend in a certain particular. This was agreed to by a decided majority.
HENRIETTA DEMPSEY, a woman of intemperate habits, was found dead in her apartments at No. 46 Essex-street, yesterday.

A fracas occurred yesterday afternoon in front of Tammany Hall, in East Fourteenthstreet, which it is feared may result in the death of the person attacked. It appears that for some weeks the Tammanyites of the Sixteenth Assembly District, which consists of the greater portion of the Eighteenth Ward, have been in a ferment, owing to the new enrollment of the Tammany voters in that district.

The search of Capt. CAMERON'S officers for JOHN O'CONNELL, alias "Coach," who, with the ex-pugilist and political bruiser, OWNEY GEOGHEGAN, and the no less criminally prominent "Clipper" HENNESSY, on Tuesday evening shot and brutally beat MICHAEL McNALLY, a Democratic inspector of election, in front of Tammany Hall, proved successful yesterday evening.

In the heart of the City of Dublin, almost facing its old Parliament-house, stands a vast and stately pile inclosed within railings. Lounging about the entrance are some lazylooking "loons" in black velvet hunting-caps. Enter, and you find a succession of spacious sombre courts. This is " Old Trinity," the single college forming Oxford and Cambridge's "silent sister," the University of Dublin. It was founded by Queen ELIZABETH.

WASHINGTON, April 24. The Goat Island bill occupied the attention of the House for two hours today, and was finally passed. The filibustering was kept up for some time, in spite of the fact that every reasonable proposition of the minority was accepted by Mr. WHEELER.

CINCINNATI, April 24. There does not seem any chance whatever for the fusion of the discordant elements about to assemble. So far as the soreheads or Liberal Republicans are concerned, they may succeed in effecting an apparent pacification among themselves, by nominating candidates without any platform, but this course will not satisfy the Democrats, or such Republicans as have cast their lot with the Reunion and Reform Association.

The Governor has finished the perusal of the engrossed copy of the New-York Charter, and is now awaiting the arguments of the friends and opponents of the measure. He will devote to-morrow, between the hours of 10 and 4 o'clock, to the hearing, when any and all persons interested in the charter will have an opportunity to present their views.

Only a few years ago ship-building was a live business here, and the ship-yards which were situated principally along and on both sides of East River, presented an animated scene. The ship-joiner's eight-hour strike in 1866 sounded the knell of this branch of mechanics, and now the yards are, for the most part, silent and deserted.

Few anniversaries in modern times have been anticipated with as much interest as the Centennial in 1876. Although more than four years off, definite preparations for it have already been commenced. The place where it is to be held has been designated; and deliberations, not only as to the general arrangement, but many of the details, have for several months been actively going on.

The African M.E. Zion Church Connection reassembled yesterday at 9 A.M., Bishop CLINTON presiding. Brother LOWERY arose to ask the advice of the Conference. His congregation had agreed, during the last two years, to pay him a salary of $250. During that time he had only received $28. He wanted to know if there was not some way for him to obtain relief without resorting to legal proceedings.

WASHINGTON, April 25. The Senate Arms Investigation Committee met today for consultation, all the members present, and, after a general interchange of views, adjourned for another consultation next week. A resolute effort will be made to secure a unanimous report, and to that end the majority of the Committee are willing to yield all technical differences and minor points.

The Governor spent a couple of hours this morning in listening to an informal discussion upon the merits of the New-York Charter, and the constitutionality of the cumulative voting feature. The discussion, or rather desultory conversation, was carried on principally between HENRY L. CLINTON, who opposed the charter, and Gov. SALOMON and SIMON STERNE, who defended it the Governor listening patiently to the talk, but taking very little part in it.

SALT LAKE CITY, April 26. The release of BRIGHAM YOUNG excites no special comment except from the Press. The Herald says hundreds of thousands congratulate him. The Tribune says, "We owe our present quiet to his caution and sagacity."

This city was once more thrown into intense excitement this morning. The news of another fire-damp explosion at the Pine Brook Colliery spread with the rapidity of lightning. From the statements received by cable about the eruption of Mount Vesuvius, it will naturally be presumed that the inhabitants of Naples and the surrounding country are in an unenviable and unhappy condition. In point of fact, however, the Neapolitans are probably elated and happy beyond their usual careless habit.

All things tend to show that the long and cruel Winter has ceased, and that the mild, loving Heretha, goddess beloved of our ancestors, has come to reign over us. Under the benign influence of the soft, warm showers, the black buds of the ash are showing tiny points of green, and the horse-chestnuts give glorious promise of future thick foliage and pyramids of blossoms.

But this affair presents peculiar features meriting closer attention.

The subject of increasing the supply of fishes in fresh waters has occupied the attention of mankind from a very remote period. "When sorrows come," says the great poet, "they come not single spies but in battalions." Those who know books better than men, or who reason coldly from the abstract nature of things, may regard this idea as a superstition. Experience, notwithstanding, so often confirms it, that the question may well occur whether what may be termed the gregariousness of misfortunes is not due to some natural if, as yet, occult law.

The act known as Assembly bill No.965 now awaits its final passage in the lower House of the Legislature. That bill, in addition to other small claims, provides for the payment of some seventeen thousand dollars in discharge of salary, and part of the heavy legal expenses of Ex-Supervisor JOHN FOLEY, during his long and successful contest in the Courts with the Tammany Ring.

The weekly meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held yesterday afternoon, the President in the chair. As there were only ten members present, merely ordinary routine business, involving no considerable expenditure of money, was transacted.

The examination of ALBERT VAN SAUN, charged with forgery, was resumed yesterday, at the Tombs Police Court, before Judge DOWLING. District-Attorney SULLIVAN appeared for the prosecution, and H.L. CLINTON and A.W. TENNEY for the defense.

ALBANY, May 13.--The Assembly met at 7 this evening, and immediately plunged into a passionate discussion of the TIMES' articles of the last two days on the subject of the impeachment proceedings, which were introduced as a question of privilege by Mr. ALVORD.

The Winter was prolonged in so unusual a way that the advent of fine weather was hailed with joy by builders all over the City, and edifices began to go up of to be pulled down in every direction. Carpenters and joiners had their hands full, and it would have been hard Fast Saturday morning to have found a single one who was out of work.

The Methodist General Conference met at the usual hour yesterday morning, Bishop AMES presiding. Dr. F.G. HIBBARD, of East Genesse led the devotional exercises. The audience was thin at the opening, but increased gradually until the Academy was well filled.

NASHVILLE, May 13. The Spring meeting on the Blood Horse Association Course opened today with two races. The weather was fine, the track in good condition, and the attendance large. The first race was an agreed stake for four-year olds, entrance $50, mile heats, for a purse of $400.
The remains of an unknown man were found in the East River, yesterday, at Pier No. 34 and were removed to the Morgue.

The controversy which is just now taking place in regard to the condition of the Croton water, has created some uneasiness among a considerable class in this City, and the Board of Health, in conjunction with the Croton Department, have determined by a proper examinaton to ascertain the truth of the charges relative to the impure nature of the water.
Mr. POMEROY, from the Committee on Public Lands, reported a bill to create an additional land district in Kansas. Passed.

The series of Summernight concerts at the Central Park Garden was commenced last evening, under most auspicious circumstances. Pleasant weather, an exceedingly large audience, and a capital recital of a varied programme, left nothing to be desired.

Yesterday, Gen. SHERMAN and Lieut. GRANT, accompanied the American Minister to the Palace of Dolma Bagtche for the purpose of taking leave of the Sultan and of expressing their deep sense of obligation for the great kindness with which His Majesty had been graciously pleased to welcome them to his capital, and the very flattering attentions which had been shown them during their stay.

WASHINGTON, D.C., May 16. The Secretary of the Interior has received a communication from Gen. HOWARD dated Tucson, Arizona, April 27 Who says he spent four days at Camp Grant in order to inquire thoroughly into the Apache troubles at the spot which has been considered its centre.

The great event of the week in Continental European politics is the closing of the Hungarian Parliament by Emperor FRANCIS JOSEPH. The act was performed with peculiar display, and this was done not without intention. The session which has now come to an end has been barren of the great events which were intended to eternalize it in the annals of history.

Fleetwood Park yesterday was the scene of one of the most exciting contests that has taken place in this vicinity in a long time, and from the peculiar circumstances under which the race was decided, no less than the reputations of the horses entered, created a great deal of excitement, which culminated yesterday.

There has been a lull in the telegraphic congratulations which, according to the Tribune, poured in upon Mr. GREELEY a few days since, from Jersey City, Flushing. Yaphank and other Political centres. DETROIT, Mich., May 16. Information from loughton, received last night, regarding the strike of the copper-miners, states that on Tuesday morning a portion of the men who are satisfied with the terms offered by the Mining Superintendents announced their desire to resume work. Upon proceeding to do so, they were interfered with, when the Sheriff summoned 100 special deputies from among the citizens of Hancock and Houghton to protect the workmen.

SCRANTON, Penn., May 16. Persons just returned from the scene of the terrific mountain fires in the neighborhood of Tobyhanna, report that the village was entirely surrounded by fire on Wednesday about 1 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, May 16. The Japanese Embassy are now nearly ready to take their departure from this city. They will, when they leave here, visit Philadelphia, New-York and West Point, and then proceed to Boston, whence they will sail for Europe next week.

Fearing the spread of contagious diseases, about six months since the Board of Health in this City passed a resolution forbidding the landing of rags from vessels at any of our docks and piers, except under such severe restrictions as to shut them out almost entirely, and as the importation of this material for supplying the paper-mills is quite an extensive business interest in this City, there was considerable consternation among importers of rags.

It seems that nothing short of an earthquake or a fit of sickness can bring me to a sense of my duty as a correspondent. Arrested in mid career of jaunting and junketing, gadding and gossiping, by a severe influenza. I nave a little space for reflection and repentance. while looking down from the window of my sick-chamber on the bright, busy world, a part of which I was so little while ago.

The multitudinous benevolent associations and schemes in which Mr. WOLFE was interested drew together a congregation of associates and friends, to attend his funeral obsequies, so large as to fill the church, Representatives of all the principal charitable societies were present, as was the host of friends who loved and esteemed him for his social virtues.

The depositors of the Bowling-Green Savings Bank have the satisfaction of learning that, on Monday last, that collapsed institution was finally withdrawn from bankruptcy. It is exactly six months since the Court of Bankruptcy appointed Mr. SHEPPARD KNAPP receiver of the suspended savings bank, and shortly after this appointment Mr. MAY, a depositor, whose claim amounted to $9,000, made application to the Court, and through his efforts the bank was adjudicated bankrupt.

WASHINGTON, May 23. The Finance Committee substantially finished the tariff portion of the tax bill today, and are to-night engaged on the internal revenue portion. They have left coal and salt as in the House bill; lumber has been changed from the rate in the House bill, which places it in the horizontal ten per cent. list, to $2 per thousand on pine, with similar reduction on other grades.

WASHINGTON, D.C., May 23.--Dispatches to the Navy Department from Rear-Admiral RODGERS, commanding the Asiatic fleet, dated Nagasaki, Japan, April 9, inform the Department that the Colorado reached Nagasaki April 8, from Amoy and Hong Kong. She would proceed to Yokohoma, where Rear Admiral Jenkins was to relieve Admiral Rodgers of the command of the fleet.

The Oceanic Yacht Club of Jersey City held their annual reception at the boat-house, at the foot of Van Vorst-street, Jersey City, last evening.

MADRID, May 25. The Carlist bands which were announced yesterday as having appeared in some of the provinces, and cut the telegraph wires, have not yet been suppressed. They are still active, and continue to sever railroad and telegraph communication between various points.

Some years ago Mr. PARTON wrote a biography of Mr. GREELEY. NOW that the latter is a candidate for the Presidency, (subject to the indorsement of the Democratic Convention,) a new and enlarged edition of this biography is to be issued.
A collection of 229 oil-paintings and 106 water-color drawings have been on view at the Leavitt Art Galleries, in Broadway, during the week.

A desperate shooting affray took place in Mercer-street, near Waverley-place, about 11 o'clock last night. WILLIAM GOULD, an ex-policeman and "sport" GEORGE ANDERSON, a bar-tender, WILLIAM DEVINE, bar-tender, of No. 86 Second-street, and a wellknown Broadway personage called "Cap," came out of an infamous house kept by EMMA COZZENS in Mercer-street at that hour. GOULD and "Cap" walked ahead.
WASHINGTON, May 25. The Senate at 9 o'clock to-night, by a vote of 42 to 9, passed a resolution advising the President to negotiate the Supplemental article to the Treaty of Washington.

Being temporarily detained in New-Orleans from a proposed trip through Mexico, I determined to fill the gap with a visit to the Indian Nation and Texas. Outfitting with a suit of coarse home-spun, a broad-brim, a lead pencil, and a mosquito bar, I boarded one of the Red River steamers, and in nine days (days of crooked traveling) landed at Jefferson, the then head of navigation.

Police Surgeons STANLEY and VAN BUREN were dismissed by the Board of Police yesterday.

The eating-house I frequent is, I think, entirely given up to professional people. Situated near two theatres, an opera house and a circus, I am led to suppose that a good many persons employed on the stage take their dinners there, before the curtain rises, and sup there after the closing of the house.

The Herald which at present is the organ of the Roman Catholic Church of New-York is attempting to arouse a contemptible sectarian feeling among the poor Catholics against the House of Refuge, on account of its Protestant management.

The religious exercises of the Conference yesterday were conducted by Rev. STEPHEN ALLEN, of Maine. A motion of Rev. Mr. HUNT, Chairman of the Reception Committee, was adopted, to receive the delegates of the Baptist Home Mission Association on Monday next, at 11 o'clock.
The Newark Common Council have passed an ordinance making it obligatory upon bakers to stamp upon all loaves the precise weight, together with the name of the owner.

The annual exodus has set in, and outward bound steam-ships are crammed with travelloving Americans on their way to get a first, or a twentieth, look at Europe. It is customary on these occasions for a portion of the Press to lift up its voice in deprecation.
There seems to be prevalent just now in England a curious mania for obtaining money under false pretenses. In the prosecution of these frauds the most singular devices are resorted to.
Yesterday afternoon the Atlantic Boat Club of Hoboken, one of the oldest rowing associations in this locality, inaugurated the boating season of 1872 with two races and a banquet.

There has been little to call for fresh note at the New-York theatres during the week. "London Assurance" has kept the bills at Wallack's, "Humpty Dumpty" has done no less at the Olympic, Mr. JOHNNY THOMPSON has been "On Hand" at Wood's Museum, and "Article 47" has been repeated ad nauseam at the Fifthavenue.
The Fleetwood Association wound up its Spring meeting yesterday, and despite a clouded sky and other depressing influences, the meeting closed successfully.
I often wonder if when, as the Bible tells us, " the secrets of all our hearts shall be revealed," they will be revealed to our fellow-creatures as well as to the Almighty Judge of men.
Gov. HOFFMAN has left Albany to be absent a month.

Mr. SUMNER called the attention of the Senate to a report in the NEW-YORK TIMES representing him to have said, in Executive Session, that Great Britain should have been promptly notified, when she pro posed to break up the Tribunal, that the result would be war.
The body of an unknown man was found, yesterday, floating in the water at pier No. 26 North River.

WASHINGTON, May 25. The House was not in session today, having exhausted itself by its all night struggle, which was the mere contest of will between a majority who wanted to pass a claim and a minority who didn't. The claim involved the principle of paying for property within the enemy's lines destroyed in the act of war.
The Police made 557 arrests during the past week.
Great preparations are already being made by the officers and members of the Seventh Regiment for their approaching encampment at Saratoga, and affairs seem to be in a forward condition.

Miss CLARA LOUISE KELLOGG made her reappearance in London, as Drury-lane Theatre, on May 11. The newspapers are filled with complimentary references to her performance she sang Linda, in DONIZETTI'S wellknown opera and all record her cordial reception and the excellent impression, shown by applause and recalls of her singing and acting. Miss KELLOGG was to sing next in "Lucia di Lammermoor" ....
Eighteen hundred and thirty persons were arrested by the Police last week, and 2,144 vagrants were accommodated with lodgings at the various Police stations.
The will of JOSIAH MACY, Sr., of Harrison, deceased, conveying over $300,000 in personal estate, was admitted to probate on Friday.

The deliberate attempt made at an early hour yesterday morning by ROBERT L. CRAWFORD, a brother-in-law of Commodore CORNELIUS VANDERBILT, to murder Detective WM. HENDERSON, of the Fifteenth Precinct, already referred to in the TIMES, created the most intense excitement throughout the Police Department yesterday, and the members of the force eagerly discussed the details of the affair.

A committee of the cabinet-makers, woodcarvers, upholsterers and others employed in the cabinet making trade was in session yesterday, and received additional reports of the results of the operations of the different committees.

Nothing in modern politics is so marvelous as the confidence of Mr. GREELEY that he is to be the elect of the American people in November next.

Fulton Ferry is the big end of one of the funnels that discharge population out of NewYork. On the other side is the big end of a like funnel, which serves a like purpose for Brooklyn. Thirty-nine million passengers crossed at that point last year.

The spotted fever is prevailing with unwonted fatality in some portions of Pennsylvania.

Since the publication of Mr. GREELEY'S elaborate letter formally accepting the nomination of the Cincinnati Convention for President of the United States, we have been fairly inundated with letters from persons who have been subscribers to the New-York Tribune.

Many readers of the TIMES would have been pleased to attend the demonstration in favor of the re-election of GRANT and Gov. CALDWELL at our city Hall last night. The Governor is now in the midst of a brilliant campaign, and has already visited the principal places in the State.
Judge COX yesterday committed WM. ROGERS, a shoemaker, for having stolen $38 worth of dry goods from JOHN MASON.
WASHINGTON, D.C., May 25. The Tariff and Tax bill has been reported to the Senate. The Committee on Finance propose that the act shall take effect on the 1st of July next instead of January, 1873:

Murder appears to be the only amusement of Mercer-street. The little affair of Saturday morning, when an officer and a citizen, were shot down by a qentleman with the infirmity of a hot temper, was promptly supplemented within the next twenty-four hours by some pistol practice that would have been no disgrace to frontier desperadoes.

The investigation set on foot yesterday by Capt. BYRNES, of the Fifteenth Precinct, to discover the person who had shot GARDINER DEVINE and THEODORE ANDERSON during the street melee in Mercer-street on Sunday morning, as reported in yesterday's TIMES, has resulted successfully, and the mystery which before surrounded the case has been cleared up, although the persons engaged in the affrey were at first disposed to be very reticent.

Several ladies and gentlemen, interested in the welfare of the poor in our State institutions of charities, have lately organized themselves into an association for the purpose at establishing Local Visiting Committees for the almshouses, hospitals and other public institutions of charities throughout, the City and State of New-York.
Hon. JULIAN HARTRIDGE is named for the Democratic nomination for Governor of Georgia. The Chicago News has it "on reliable authority" that GREELEY will not withdraw under any possible circumstances.

The case of the bark Athena calls attention to a defect in the laws for the protection of emigrants in transit, which ought at once to be remedied. On the 4th of April, the Athena left Bremen for this port with 475 passengers in the steerage. On the second day after sailing, small-pox broke out among the crew, and speedily spread to the passengers.

Coroner HERRMANN held an inquest, yesterday, in the case of PATRICK KIERNAN, alias "Greenhorn," the young ruffian who was killed by CHRISTIAN CORDES, the proprietor of liquorstore at No. 611 Greenwich-street, on the 12th inst.

The further preparations for the approaching season point to a continuance, on the part of Caledonian clubs in American in the line of conduct indicated in our last notice. The Greenpoint Sabbath-schools will hold an anniversary on Wednesday, June 5.

A mass-meeting of the supporters of the eight-hour movements was held yesterday afternoon in front of the City Hall, stands decorated in scarlet, blue and gold, and surmounted by flags, being erected on the right and left of the main entrance. The stand nearest Broadway was set apart for the German-speaking citizens and that at the other side for English speakers. The attendance was not very large at either.

Another steam-tug exploded its boiler in the harbor yesterday, killing six and wounding four men. The wonder is not that these little boats blow up so frequently, but that we do not have ten accidents of the sort where we have one now. The engines used in these tugs are all of the high-pressure pattern, and the boilers have seldom less than ninety pounds of steam to the square inch.

MADRID, May 30. At the session of the Corter, today, Admiral TOPETE, the President of the Council, stated that the Ministry recognizes the validity of the convention made by Marshal SERRANO with the Rebels in Biscay, pardoning those who voluntarily surrender, and requested the members of the opposition not to interpellate the Government relative thereto. Upon this announcement, Senor ZORILLA arose and moved a vote of censure upon Marshal SERRANO.

Experiments are going forward, the result of which may astonish the world almost any day, for propelling railway-cars by electricity. Aerial locomotion may be, probably is, a long way off, and perhaps will never be compassed at all. But electric transit is believed by scientific men to be practicable, and, at all events, it offers no such difficulty as is involved in attempting to use a lever without a fulcrum.

The act of last Legislature amending the Game law of last year, contains one point of considerable interest to sportsmen. This is contained in the clause changing the day for commencing to shoot woodcock from the 15th to the 3d of July. The amendment in question restores this point of the law to what it was before 1871, and is regarded with considerable satisfaction by the entire fraternity of sportsmen.

PARIS, June 2. The Lucas Cotton Mills, one of the largest establishments of the kind in the vicinity of Rouen, was totally destroyed by fire yesterday. The loss is estimated at 1,000,000 francs. Nearly 1,000 operatives are thrown out of employment.

The residence of FREDERICK DOUGLASS on South avenue, just inside of the city line, was destroyed by fire last night. Shortly before midnight, Mrs. N. SPRAGUE, Mr. DOUGLASS' daughter, was awakened by smoke. On looking into the adjoining room she saw a bright light, and immediately roused her husband. He jumped from his bed and discovered the house on fire. Mrs. DOUGLASS and three of Mr. SPRAGUE'S children were sleeping upstairs.

Not long since the Corporation Counsel decided that it is necessary that legal notices for doing Corporation work must be published in one of the daily papers designated by the Mayor and Controller as Corporation paper, as well as in the official journal. The Commissioner of Public Works therefore called for proposals for advertising contracts and such work to be done under the supervision of and through the Department.

The legality of the present system of drawing Grand Juries in the United States Courts having been upheld, a new United States Grand Jury is to be drawn, in the early part of next week.

Two leagues west of Paris, on the St. Germain Railway, lies a dirty little village 'vclept Nanterre. The guide-books tell us that it is celebrated for its sausages and cakes, and boasts of a slaughter-house for pigs.

The Importers' and Grocers' Board of Trade held its annual meeting, yesterday, for the reports of committees and election of offi cers for the ensuing year. Mr. WM. A. BOOTH, President, was in the chair, Mr. WM. NEILSON, Secretary.

The twelfth annual Congress of the German Brewers of the United States, was opened yesterday morning, at the Turtle Bay Brewery Hall, in Forty-fifth-street. The delegates present numbered about 300, representing most of the Eastern, Western and Middle States. Mr. HENRY CLAUSEN was elected Chairman.

In the Court of General Sessions, Part I., yesterday, held by Judge BEDFORD, WM. LEE, colored, pleaded guilty to burglary in the third degree, and was sentenced to five years' imprisonment.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5--8 P.M.--A fitting close to the great harmony and unanimity that prevailed throughout the whole Convention was the quiet, orderly and republican manner in which the vast body of delegates returned to their hotels. Not a word, not a whisper, not a breath to disturb the general decorum and good feeling.

The group of islands in the Pacific, known indifferently as the Navigator's, or Samoan Islands, has passed into the possession, or at all events under the authority, of the United States. The cession of these islands was the joint work of two rival chiefs, whose tribes for a long time past have been waging a war of extermination with one another.

Secretary FISH returned to-night, somewhat improved by his brief rest, but still far from being in good health. The President, accompanied by Gen. PORTER, will arrive in the morning.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 18. Vice-President COLFAX and family arrived here this morning on an early train. About 8 o'clock this evenine his friends assembled in the Court-house square, to the number of 2,000 or 3,000 and, accompanied by a band, proceeded to his residence.
A little after 3 yesterday afternoon a fire broke out on the second floor of the three-story brick building Nos. 322,324 and 326 West Thirtyninth street, occupied as a brewery by ANDREW FINK.
BOSTON, June 18.--The weather continues propitious. The heat, however, is more oppressive than on the first day of the jubilee, and hence the less populous look of the streets of Boston this morning.

An evening Republican paper credits Mr. CORBETT, United States Senator from Oregon, with being a Democrat, and also a Greeley man. This is an amazing error. Mr. CORBETT is a sound Republican, in no wise tainted with Greeleyism, who has been very active in organizing the party in his State. To the victory which determines the result of the elections in Oregon, California, and probably Nevada, in November, he largely contributed.

New-Brunswick, N.J., presented a busy scene yesterday, on the occasion of the Commencement of Rutgers College. The week is the closing one of the 101st year of the College. The day was devoted to the meetings of classes, the Alumni meeting, the address before the literary societies, the dedication of the newly-completed Geological Hall, and the Junior oratorical contest.

In the case of the Second-avenue Railroad Company against tho Mayor, , in which an injunction had been issued restraining the defendant in the person of the Dock Commissioners from removing certain spiles driven down by the Railroad Company in the Harlem River, at the end of Second-avenue, a motion was made, yesterday, in Supreme Court, Chambers, on behalf of the City against the continuance of the injunction.
Hon. C.J. FAULKNER is a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Congress in the Second District of West Virginia.

ALBANY, June 18. The Senate met in ex- tra session, pursuant to adjournment, at 4 P.M. today, to continue the investigation of the charges against Judge PRINDLE, of Chenango County, and Judge McCUNN, of New-York. Not more than a dozen spectators were present.

The New-York City Council of Political Reform has recently issues its first annual report, which takes a very philisophical and business-like view of the political situation of this unfortunate City, and of its own undertaking to correct it.

The Assistant District-Attorney said that he would not present any more witnesses, and rested the case for the people.

The Commissioners of Public Instruction met yesterday afternoon Hon. B. SMITH in the chair, and Commissioners Brennan, Lewis, Duryea, Wood, Sands, James, Van Vorst, Jenkins being present.

Prof. THACHER, of Yale College, left New-Haven yesterday morning, to see what he could do in Wall-street toward completing a fund for a new chapel. In a few moments, he secured the necessary funds, and returned in the afternoon a firm believer in the generosity of Wall-street. Among the larger donors were MOSES TAYLOR, $3,000, GEORGE BLISS, $2,000, WM. E. DODGE, $3,000, S.B. CHITTENDEN, $5,000.

A special meeting of the Board of Supervisors was held at 1 o'clock yesterday to consider the oondition of the new County Court House and the appointment of a janitor and others for its care. The Committee on Civil Courts, to whom these matters were referred, reported, stating the necessity of immediate action being taken, and presenting four resolutions.

The New-Yorker Journal, of yesterday, contained the following additional item: "President GRANT is again at Long Branch, the favorite resort of blacklegs and street-walkers. GREELEY loves the writing-table, the books, the library, the garden and the silent solitude of ChappaquaGRANT likes better to attend horse-races, cock-fights, carousals, and feels nowhere more at home than in the frivolous society of Long Branch."

A resolution was passed at the meeting yester- day agreeing not to employ society men in future.

The Tilden-Butler suit was resumed yesterday in the United States Circuit Court, with the further examination of Capt. PUFFER, but nothing new was elicited from his testimony. JOHN S. SUTPHEN testified he advanced money to purchase the Nassau, and subsequently became two-thirds owner of her.

The Long anticipated trial of EDWARD S. STOKES, charged with the murder of JAMES FISK, Jr., at the Grand Central Hotel, in this City, on the afternoon of the 6th of January last, was formally commenced on the issue of fact, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday.

The Prospect Park Fair Grounds was the scene of an exciting trot yesterday, between THOS. JACKSON's b. g. Mystery, and HIRAM HOWE'S sorrel gelding with no name, two-mile heats, in harness. The weather was all that could be desired, and the track was in the most superb condition.

The annual regatta of the New-York Yacht Club is looked forward to with pleasure by numerous citizens of New-York, on account of the standing of the organization, the number of excellent yachts belonging to it, and the hospitality of its members.

Last Winter the TIMES called attention to the fact that the City Railroad Companies escaped their due proportion of taxation on their personal property, and that the license fees were not paid up regularly.
The election in West Virginia for State officers occurs Aug. 22.

The annual migration to Europe is now in full tide. The steamers are crowded, and it is difficult for those who have not long ago engaged their places to get desirable accommodations. That this travel across the ocean, apart from all its commercial and pecuniary advantages, is of eminent benefit to our country, is a fact which no one disputes.
The trial of EDWARD S. STOKES for the murder of JAMES FISK, JR., was resumed in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, yesterday, before Judge INGRAHAM.

The litigation between GORDON GORDON and JAY GOULD was again before Judge BRADY, in the Supreme Court, yesterday. It will be remembered that in this suit, in which Mr. GOR- DON is plaintiff against GOULD as defendant, counsel for the latter obtained an order for the examination of Mr. GORDON.

BATON ROUGE, La., June 20. The Pinch- back Convention met again this morning, and, after desultory denunciations of the Customhouse as not wanting a union, because they suppose GRANT is strong enough in the State, adjourned until the afternoon.

The trial of FREDERICK E. ROWALD, the Hoboken City Clerk, who embezzled city funds, has been postponed to Tuesday next.

BOSTON, June 20. The largest audience of the week was gathered in the Coliseum today. A reduced rate of admission undoubtedly increased the attendance, for the programme was scarcely attractive enough to make the appear- ance of an unusually large attendance probable.

The case of Dr. GEO. R. GYLES, charged with causing the death of Mrs. MARY A. LOWDEN by malpractice, was resumed yesterday in the Court of General Sessions, before Judge BEDFORD. Counsel for the prisoner submitted twenty-nine legal propositions, on which he requested the Court to charge the jury as matters of law.

The Greeley managers, who have been wandering about the country endeavoring, and as we hope with some success, to attach the Democratic Party as a somewhat large tail to their ridiculously little Liberal kite, will be early in the Monumental City, prepared to play all sorts of fantastic tricks for the benefit of the Tammany favorite.
The most sanguine and undoubtedly the best organized combination, the Iron and Metal Worker's Eight-Hour League, met in considerable number in Germania Assembly Rooms yesterday morning.

The Congregational Church of Riverhead has extended a call to Rev. W.J. CHALMERS, of New-York.

TROW'S City Directory for the year ending May, 1873, has just been published. The Directory affords, from year to year, a fair indication of the growth of our population, and the patient collector of statistics could draw from it accurate information as to the industrial changes that take place among us.

Fifteen members of the Eight-hour League waited upon Superintendent KELSO yesterday morning and complained of the alleged ill-treatment which members of the League had been subjected to by the Police force detailed to guard establishments in which the men who had been on a strike had resumed work.
Hon. S.S. COX, who is stopping at Long Branch, is regaining his health and strength.

The University of the City of New-York held its annual Commencement yesterday morning in the Academy of Music. The hour fixed for the opening of the proceedings was 10, but long before that time all the available seats in the parquet, family circle, and first tier were occupied by a fashionable assemblage, glowing in all the bright colors of Spring fashions.

The much-vaunted "Conference" among the opponents of the Republican ticket has amounted to nothing. It adjourned this morning at 1 o'clock, after nearly ten hours of speech-making, leaving the acceptance or rejection of Mr. GREELEY'S candidature precisely where it was when the Conference commenced.

The regular June meeting of the Peninsular Fruit-growers' Association, preceding the gathering and harvesting of the peach crop. was held, yesterday afternoon, at Dover. It was ascertained that arrangements for transportation could be made for through shipments to Boston with comparatively little additional cost to that already paid to Jersey City.

ALBANY, June 20. The Senate reassem- bled at 10 A.M., all the Senators being present except AMES, BOWEN, O'BRIEN and TWEED. In justice to Senator AMES it should be stated that he has been confined to his house by severe sickness for four months past.

WASHINGTON, June 20. Among important measures introduced last session, but remaining without action, was the law reorganizing the Patent Office, of which a full explanation was published during the Winter.

The Convention of the Liberal Republican Party in New-Jersey was held yesterday, at Library Hall, Newark, in pursuance of a call issued by Cols. SCOVEL, FREESE and others. The Convention was called to order at 12 by Mr. F.A. SNYDER, of Jersey City, who nominated Judge GALE, of Rahway, as permanent Chairman. At this time about fifty delegates and from 100 to possibly 200 outsiders were present.
