At the Exchange yesterday, (Thursday, June 20,) MULLER, WILKINS Co. sold at public auction one lot, 25.8 by 100, situate on the north-east corner of Ninth-avenue and Eightysecond-street, for $7,650, and one lot, 25.6 by 100, adjoining, fronting on avenue, for $5,675, both purchased by A. LEVY; no other sales were made.
The Health Department report 230 deaths last week, of which only fourteen were occasioned by small-pox. The total number is twenty-eight in excess over the corresponding week last year.
The great Tilden-Butler suit, which has been occupying the attention of the United States Circuit Court for the past week, termi- nated, yesterday, in a complete victory for Gen. BUTLER.

The organs of the soreheads and bolters seem to derive a gloomy kind of satisfaction from the statement that the regular Republi- can newspapers burst into loud laughter when HORACE GREELEY'S nomination was first announced, but are now quaking with horrible fears.

The production in London of the new opera, "Gelmina," has drawn much attention to its celebrated composer, Prince PONIATOWSKI. The fall of the Empire exiled the Prince from France, and he, the grand nephew and representative of STANISLAUS, the last King of Poland, has been forced to seek a livelihood through the exercise of his musical talents in London.
WASHINGTON, June 21. The following circular will be issued to-morrow by the Acting Commissioner of Pensions:

The first canoe cruise of any consequence yet made by American canoes was successfully sailed by two of the New-York Canoe Club's diminutive yachts last week. The canoes started from Staten Island, and going outside the Hook skirted the coast of Long Island for some distance, occasionally running in at convenient inlets, and cruising in the bays that form a distinctive feature of the South shore of the Island.
BATON ROUGE, La., June 21. Hon. P.B. DARRELL was renominated this morning unanimously for Congress in the Third District Convention.

The first game of the annual series for the New-Jersey State championship came off at Waverley, N.J., yesterday, the contestants being the Champions, of Jersey City, (the present possessors of the pennant,) and the Resolutes, of Elizabeth. CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 21. Class Day at Harvard was celebrated today, and the sky being cloudless there was nothing whatever to interfere with its perfect enjoyment. Brilliant crowds attended the ceremonies and festivities crowds of wonderfully pretty girls as well as crowds of prominent people.

The first summer meeting of the Monmouth Park Association at Long Branch will begin on Saturday next, June 29. It is not the mere fact that the races are coming that is arousing the enthusiasm which is so observable, but the consummation of the long desired object of bringing into competition the two greatest horses that have been seen on the turf for years.

BOSTON, Mass., June 21. The audience this afternoon was fully equal in numbers and enthusiasm to that of yasterday. The Ameri- can National Hymn, words by HOLMES and music by KELLER, was the first executed by the chorus, orchestra and bands, and it was admirably given.

The trial of EDWARD S. STOKES for the murder of JAMES FISK, Jr., was resumed yesterday morning before Judge INGRAHAM, in the Court of Oyer and Termiuer. The prisoner was represented by his counsel, Messrs. McKRON, DAILEY and TOWNSEND, and the prosecution was conducted by the District-Attorney, assisted by the private counsel, Messrs. BEACH and FULLERTON. Three additional jurors were impaneled during the day, making seven now already sworn in.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 21. A boiler in the extensive shops of the Ohio Brush and Wire Works, located within the walls of the Ohio Penitentiary, exploded, this morning, just after the convicts had started to work, with a terrible noise and effect.
There is a serious split in the Democratic Party of San Francisco. It is worse than any since that of 1860.

The opponents of the Government in this country, like the opponents of Gen. GRANT in the United States, appear to have some difficulty in making up their minds whether it would suit their game better that the treaty should collapse or that it should be carried through.

A grand rally of the Republicans of Kings County, to ratify the nominations of GRANT and WILSON, took place last evening at the Academy of Music, Brooklyn. Notwithstanding the intense heat, which rendered attendance at a political meeting extremely uncomfortable, an immense concourse of people assembled in the spacious hall, occupying every available seat in the parquet and galleries.

NAVARRO for the delivery of a number of watermeters at $70 each. WASHINGTON, June 22. The Trade-marks Convention between the United States and the Austro-Hungarian Empire has been proclaimed by the President, and will take effect from the 22d day of July, to continue in force for ten years.

BELLEVILLE, Ontario, June 22. The citizens of this town are very much excited today In consequence of a dreadful accident occurring on the Grand Trunk Railway, a few miles below, and the disaster makes the more sensation because it is the first that has occurred on this division of the road since the line opened in 1858.

A terrible catastrophe occurred yesterday morning at the chemical laboratory of GEO. A. ERKENBRACH, located on the first floor of the five-story bring building, Nos. 18 and 20 Libertystreet, resulting in fearful injuries to no fewer than twenty persons, several of whom, it is feared, will not survive their injuries. The action of the Free Traders, who met in solemn conclave at the Fifth-avenue Hotel on Friday, in nominating WM. S. GROESBECK and FRED. LAW OLMSTED as their candidated for the Presidency and Vice-Presidency, caused considerable comment in this City yesterday, as such action was wholly unexpected after the total failure of the Sore-head "Conference" of the day before.

Judge BEDLE yesterday passed sentence upon Commissioners EDMONDSON, GOITRE, GROSS, HUTTON, and Chief of Police MCWILLIAMS, who were convicted at the last term of the Hudson County Court of defrauding the city.

BOSTON, June 22.--The first meeting of the compaign in the ancient and honorable Faneuil Hall and in Boston, in ratification of the cominations at Philadelphia of GRANT and WILSON, took place to-night. A large crowd attended, and the enthusiasm of the occasion was of the old-fashioned and sterling sort.

Applications to have the price of a seat refunded, on the score of dissatisfaction with the performance, are not altogether unknown at theatrical boy-offices. How often they are complied with we do not know, but to the maker of such a demand it no doubt seems natural and reasonable in the extreme.

At a meeting of the Board of Aldermen, held on the 3d inst., a petition was presented from the Anti-monopoly association asking that a thorough investigation be made in relation to the lighting of the City, and that the expense at which citizens can be provided with gas by the City be ascertained. The petition was referred to the Committee on Finance, composed of, Messrs. MEHRBACK, (Chairman,) VANCE and WILDER.

ST. LOUIS, June 22. The meeting of the Republicans of St. Louis, to ratify the nomination of GRANT and COLFAX, took place to-night, and in point of magnitude and the manifestation of an earnest satisfaction at the choice of the Philadelphia Convention was not surpassed by any political gathering held in the city since the compaign of 1868.

The trial of EDWARD S. STOKES for the murder of JAMES FISK, Jr., was resumed yesterday before Judge INGRAHAM, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer. Two additional jurors were inpaneled, making, together with those already sworn in, nine jurors. The prisoner was represented, as usual, by his counsel, Messrs. McKEON, DAILY and TOWNSEND, and the prosecution was conducted by District-Attorney GARVIN, assisted by the private counsel, Messrs. BEACH and FULLERTON.

BATON ROGUE, June 22.--The Regular Convention at once proceeded to balloting for Governor on assembling, amidst great excitement. On the first ballot there was no choice. A delegate raised a terrific storm by declaring from the platform that money was being used to defeat Senator KELLOGG. Five minutes' indescribable confusion ensued.

HAVANA, Saturday, June 15, 1872. News received from Spanish and Cuban sources announces a projected movement on the part of the Cubans, intended to revive the waning fortunes of those who are still holding out against the resources and strength of the soldiers from Spain, the deserters and traitors from their own ranks, and the union of the Island Spaniards, cemented by the bayonets of the Volunteers.

On the 7th of March last the Chronicle printed the history of the romantic love-match made years ago between the great actress, MATILDA HERON, and the late HARRY BYRNE. That publication created the greatest interest throughout the country, being copied in hundreds of Eastern newspapers, and eliciting a world of comment wherever the fame of the woman had preceded.

The Church of St. John the Baptist, in West Thirtieth-street, near Seventh-avenue, was dedicated yesterday to the service of God according to the ritual of the Roman Church. At 9 o'clock tho doors of the Church were opened and the crowd poured into the edifice, soon filling all the available seats.

Mr. WM. BLACKMORE, an English capitalist and the distinguished founder of the Blackmore Museum at Salisbury, is about starting out from Denver on an extended tour over the Rocky Mountain region. He will be accompanied by Mrs. BLACKMORE, Gon. COWEN, the Assistant Secretary of the Interior, and Col. JOHN DELANO, son of Secretary DELANO.

President McCOSH, of Princeton College, (College of New Jersey,) yesterday, delivered the Baccalaureate Sermon to the class of 1872, the one hundred and twenty-fifth class to graduate from Nassau Hall. A meeting of the Employers' Central Executive Committee was held in the Hoffman House to receive reports from the different employers. It was determined to adhere to the resolutions passed at the last meeting, and also to form an organization among the men to counteract the effect of the Trades-Union organization.

BELLEVILLE, Ontario, June 24.?Our people are still at work in caring for the passengers injured by the terrible accident on the Grand Trunk on Saturday. The scenes at the temporary hospital are very painful. Thirty persons have died already, and many others are rapidly sinking.
The Central Liberal Republican Club was organized in Paterson last evening at a meeting held in the office of the Dale Silk Manufacturing Company, T.N. DALE, President.

WASHINGTON, July 2. Several boundary lines between States are to be surveyed and accurately determined, under the direction of the Interior Department. These lines are required to be determined astronomically, and only surveyors who are able to so determine them will be employed; or, if other parties are employed, they will be compelled to employ assistants qualified to make the necessary observations and computations to make determinations of the character above mentioned.

Rev. E.M. Shultz, missionary in the Five Points, makes the following report of his work for the past five days:

It is many a long day since I have sat me down to have a chat with you. It may have been an interval of relief to you, very possibly; but it is not meet that you should enjoy too much happiness in this world for fear you may not want to leave it when your time comes. So I will be your penance, and for the nonce renew my "distinguished considerations."

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 18. The first important Republican ratification meeting in Connecticut was held here this evening under the auspices of the State Central Committee. At least 4,000 ladies and gentlemen, the intelligence and respectability of the city assembled under the spreading elms in front of the Statehouse, and in the most enthusiastic and earnest manner gave decided indorsement to the Republican Party and its standard-bearers, Grant and Wilson.

MADRID, July 19 Evening. Their Majesties the King and Queen assisted at a "Te Deum" in the Royal Chapel today. The King subsequently walked through the streets, and was cheered with enthusiasm by the people.

MADRID, July 19 6 A.M. At midnight last night, as the King and Queen were returning from the palace garden to the palace, five men, conveniently posted in Arnal-street, fired upon the carriage. Its occupants were uninjured. One of the assassins was immediately killed by an attendunt on the royal party, and the others were captured.

MADRID, Aug. 24. It is now known that the Government has received information of an organized plan for an insurrection in the disaffected provinces in the north. The time fixed by the revolutionists for their uprising is the 28th of the present month. The French Government has been informed of the plans of the conspirators and requested to use precautions to prevent them receiving aid from France.
Nineteen hundred and forty-three persons were arrested by the Police in this City last week.

TORONTO, Ont., Aug. 24. The English eleven completed the first inning of their match with the Montreal twenty-two, yesterday, scoring 255 runs, of which Grace contributed 81. The Canadians then went in and made 48. When the game was resumed today the Canadians first took the bat and were put out for 67 runs, the English eleven thus winning in one inning, and by a score of 255 to 115.

The first Greeley and Brown mass-meeting of the campaign, held in Jersey City, took place at the Club-room of the Sixth District Greeley and Brown Campaign Club, last evening. Hon. Wm. B. Rankin was the first speaker. He confined his remarks chiefly to a history of the Baltimore Convention, and concluded with an appeal to the Democrats to stand by Greeley and Brown.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 3. Senator Sumner, before leaving for Europe, confided to F.W. Bird, Chairman of the Liberal Republican State Convention, for publication, a speech, which he had intended to deliver in Fancuil Hall, this evening.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Sept. 3. The files of the Treasury Department contain some interesting traces of J.B. Grinnell, the Iowa Greeley Reformer, in the Spring of 1869. Being about to visit the Indian Territory and Texas in connection with private speculations in land and rail- road matters, he importuned Commissioner Delano to give him a detective's commission for his personal protection.

The higher education of women, as illustrated by the experiment now being tried at Cambridge, England, is regarded with great interest in this country, and the evidence of progress supplied by the account of the late examination, just published, will be read here with much pleasure.

Yesterday afternoon, at the Union Ground, the Mutuals succeeded in effecting a break in their recent line of defeats, by conquering the Athletics, of Philadelphia, by a score of 18 to 11, After a game marked by considerable heavy batting and unusually indifferent fielding.

Over 5,000 persons, full of enthusiasm, assembled, last evening, in front of the rooms of the Kings County General Committee, Brooklyn, to join in raising a magnificent Grant and Wilson banner. The air was ablaze with fire works, a calcium light threw its comet-like glare, and a fine band blended its inspiring music with the pervading harmony of feeling.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 3. The murder of Hickox, the County Clerk of Pope County, is one of the most cold-blooded political assasinations ever perpetrated in this State. The Sheriff and Clerk, under the laws of this State, are im- portant officers in the holding of elections.
A. Warner, Chairman of the Mississippi Republican State Committee, and T.W. Baldwin, of Minnesota, were among the visitors at the Republican head-quarters, yesterday.

Yesterday was the first day of the series of the purses offered by the Prospect Park Fair Ground Association, and, although there were bright skies and a bracing atmosphere, the attendance was rather "thin," many of the turfmen evidently being absent from the City in attendance at the meeting of the Eastern Duchess Association at Amenia.
BERLIN, Sept. 3. Duke Maximilian Joseph, of Bavaria, and Prince Gortschakoff have arrived here.
The Board of Charities show in their annual report a reduction of $106,000 in their expenditures in one year.

A meeting of the pork packers and provision dealers was held at the Produce Exchange, yesterday afternoon, to elect delegates to the Cincinnati Convention, on the 18th inst. Abram S. Jewell, President of the Exchange presided.

LONDON, Sept. 3 11 A.M. A dispatch from Canterbury reports that a fire has just broken out over the altar in the eastern end of the magnificent cathedral in that town, and the flames are spreading rapidly. The firemen are on the ground, but no water can be obtained to throw upon the burning edifice.

The officials of the Pacific Mail Steam-ship Company have received intelligence that their famous and most valuable steamer the America was totally destroyed by fire on the 24th ult., while lying in the port of Yokohama, Japan. According to the cable telegrams from Hong Kong, via India and England, the steamer was burned to the water's edge, and is consequently a total loss, including her cargo, which consisted largely of specie.

The case of Miss Rosa McCabe, already frequently reported in the TIMES, was again before the Supreme Court, in Chambers, yesterday, Judge Leonard presiding. The hearing now is whether Miss McCabe (known in her religious order as Sister Mary Stanislaus) is atpresent sane or insane.

After a comparatively quiet canvass, Vermont yesterday held its State election. The vote was heavier than in 1870, but apparently not so heavy as in 1868. The gains and losses varied in different sections of the State. In several of the larger towns the opposition State ticket received a considerable accession of strength from the GreeleyRepublicans.

Today the Seventeenth excursion will take place. It will be composed entirely of children from the Sixth Ward, collected by Capt. Kennedy and the officers of the Franklinstreet Station-house. Tickets for this excursion were given out a week ago, and so eager was the demand for them that the street in front of the Station-house was fairly besieged. It is, therefore, probable that this picnic will be among the largest of the series.

The steamer Bremen, from Bremen, landed 387 passengers at Castle Garden yesterday. The annual term of the Female Art School of the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art will begin on the 1st day of Oc- tober.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Sept. 3--12 o'clock,-- Nothing has been received up to this time to... change the aspect as telegraphed at 10 o'clock. Eighty-six towns give Converse 22,091, and Gardener 9,222. These towns embrace about one-half the vote of the State. One hundred and one towns return ninety-five Republicans, five Democrats and one Liberal Republican to the Legislature.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Sept. 4. The inquiry into the circumstances attending the Metis disaster began on yesterday, when the Captain, mate and helmsman of the schooner Nettie Cushng, which is now here, were examined privately by Inspectors Low, Beck with and Hovey.
A seizure of four pieces of silk, five pieces of lace and ten dozen meerschaum pipes was made at Castle Garden yesterday from a passenger arriving by the steamer Bremen.

The market for New-York real estate was flat yesterday, (Wednesday,) Sept. 4. No public sales were held at the Exchange, and there were but few persons in attendance. In the brokers' offices there was but little show of business and no private sale of importance was reported.

O'Conor had been nominated by acclamation at Louisville caused considerable commotion and much profanity among many of the followers of the Baltimore bantling. Some of these worthies collected on the steps of the City Hall yesterday and exchanged opinions on the situation.

From what we are told of the Phoenix, that extraordinary fowl must have been arrayed in colors such as neither Solomon nor the gayest lily of any earthly field over ventured to adopt.

TOPEKA, Kansas, Sept. 5.--The Republican State Convention met here yesterday, but did not get organized till late last evening, and before much was done it was too late to transmit its proceedings. The strife for Governor was very bitter, and resulted, on the tenth ballot, in the nomination of T. O. Osborne, of Leavenworth.

The balloon ascension, so long postponed, took place yesterday afternoon at 5 o'clock, Prof. King and Mr. Schaeffer, the Signal Service officer, took their places in it a short time before, while hundreds of willing hands clutched the netting and held down the struggling bal- loon. A few moments were spent by the aeronaut in endeavoring to ascertain the exact amount of buoyancy necessary.
BERLIN, Sept. 5. The Emperor of Russia, the Czarowitch Alexander and the Grand Duke Vladimir arrived at the Eastern Railway Station at 2 o'clock this afternoon.
A slight frost occurred at Lewiston, Me., and vicinity, on Wednesday night, and injured vegetation in some places.

William J. Aiken, the man who, while a Police officer in the Eighteenth Precinct, com- mitted so many daring and successful burglaries, startling the City, bringing discredit on the Police, and causing householders to fear that even the men who were paid for guarding their property were thieves, was tried, yesterday, on one of the numerous indictments against him in the Court of General Sessions, before Judge Bedford.
This well-known east-side boating organization held its first regatta on wednesday afternoon on the East River.

GENEVA, Sept 5. The soiree given to-night by Mr. Charles Bowles in honor of the Board of Arbitration, was a brilliant success. The magnificent weather favored the festivities, and the guests in attendance numbered 1,500.
A large and enthusiastic meeting of the friends of Grant and Wilson was held at Riverdale on Wednesday night. Ex-Gov. Butler G. Noble and other able speakers addressed the audience.

For more than a week, Belfast, the capital of Ulster, and the most active and thriving city in the most prosperous part of Ireland, has been in a state of civil war. Orangemen and Catholics have flown at each other's throats, and a dozen stipendiary Magistrates, with five thousand armed men at their command, seemed, for a time, to be utterly powerless to enforce peace. Each day witnessed a repetition of the same disgraceful incidents.
Thos. Connors was arrested yesterday for striking Frank Gilmore, of Fifth-avenue and Seventh-street, on the head with a stone, causing a fracture of the skull.

The schooner Carleton, Capt. Albury, arrived at this port yesterday from Nassau, N.P., with six of the officers and passengers from the ill-fated steamer Bienville, which was burned at sea, in latitude 25.12, longitude 74.15, on the 15th of August. The names of the passengers by the Carleton are as follows: George W. Rea, passenger; W.B. Wood. passenger; A.S. Barney, passenger; Dr. George Badger, Surgeon; George W. Close, Steward; David Lewis, Second Steward.

The Coroner's Jury in the Gormier-Cartessier inquest, at Westbury, Wednesday, found a verdict exonerating the railroad employes from all responsibility for the accident.

Precisely how many times Mr. JAMES MACE, the chief pagilist of America, has gone forth to fight, and has returned without exchanging blows with his pretended antagonist is not a matter of consequence. The result of his numerous failures has however, brought pugilism into universal contempt, and the public has accustomed itself to believe that the average bruiser is a coward, as well as a brute.

The American Institute met last evening; President Bernard presided. Sixty-seven new members were elected. A resolution was adopted, directing that the Trustees of the Institute be requested to prepare a form of memorial to Congress, praying that body to make an early and sufficient appropriation in aid of industrial exhibitions.

The case of Miss Rosa McCabe, known in her religious order as Sister Mary Stanislaus, was continued before the Court yesterday, and still formed the subject of attraction for a number of curious spectators. The testimony taken was merely a continuation of the medical examination of Dr. Burdick, and did not vary in any essential particular from that published in the TIMES of yesterday.

The Republican canvass is being vigorously pressed in all parts of the State, and the promise is splendid, all things considered. There was trouble in Luzerne and Alleghany, but it has been healed. There is yet discontent in Lancaster and Crawford, but the close of the month will find all disaffection swept asideGen. Grant is popular everywhere, and his prestige will carry Hartranft through triumphantly.

This year's military manoeuvres in Italy will take place in the vicinity of the Ticino, and part of the operations will be a passage of the river by pontoons. The King will be at Arona in order to witness them.

At 9:40 o'clock this afternoon the defense closed, and the prosecution made no further offer. Dr. Schoeppe received the announcement very calmly.

Grant's condition during the two days of the battle, which effectually disposes of this long-standing slander.

A meeting of the Tammany Greeley and Brown, Kernan and Depew Ratification Meeting Committee was held at Tammany Hall yesterday, Algernon Sullivan, presiding. All the signs of the times point unerringly to one conclusion, and that is that the election of Gen. GRANT is an assured event, only waiting the lapse of time. It cannot be defeated or averted by any circumstances likely to occur. North Carolina anticipated the nation's verdict; Vermont followed with a crushing blow; Maine followed with the decision which alone was wanting to clear away all doubts and fears.

A procession was formed and he was escorted through the principal streets of the city.

GARRISON'S, N.Y., Sept. 27.--There was a great torchlight procession here to night of the Grant and Wilson Clubs of Garrison's and Cold Spring, followed by a serenade to Hon. Hamilton Fish, the Secretary of State. When the Clubs drew up in front of the residence of Secretary Fish, many well known Democrats of Garrison's and the neighborhood were in the assemblage.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Sept. 27.--The most magnificent ovation ever proffered a public man in Oswego County was today extended to Senator Conkling in this city. The day being peculiarly propitious, crowds of people began pouring in at an early hour. Regular and special trains on all the roads centering at this point brought hundreds of enthusiastic Republicans, as well as large delegations of Greeley and semi-Greeley men.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 27.--Advices from Matamoras state that the revolutionary General, Guerra, who has been operating in the States of Durango and Chihuhua, has reached Parras, in the State of Cohahuila, with his forces. Rocha has left Monterey for Parras, to accept their surrender.

The London Athenoeum remarks that the necessity of calling in all the aids of science is shown by the reports of the colliery inspectors for 1871, just published. They give the number of male persons employed in our coal-mines as 370,881, and the quantity of coal raised as 117,439,251 tons. There occurred 826 fatal accidents, from which there resulted 1,075 deaths. For each 169,246 tons of coal raised one miner perished.

PARIS, Oct. 11. Prince Napoleon and the Princess Clothilde, who are in this city, have received notice to leave France. MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 14. A private dispatch from Racine, Wis., says that a boat with eleven men, had just arrived there from the propeller Lac la Belle, which foundered about twenty miles off that place this morning. WATERTOWN, N.Y., via UTICA, Oct. 18.--The grandest political pageant ever witnessed in Northern New-York took place in this city today. There were fully 20,000 people gathered here to celebrate the recent Republican victories, and to show the country that Jefferson County will repudiate Greeleyism at the polls in November by 3,000 majority.
